Article Suppressing catalyst reconstruction in neutral electrolyte: stabilizing Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection of cobalt molybdate by tungsten doping for oxygen evolution reaction Zhouzhou Wang Qiancheng Zhou Li Luo Yaran Shi Haoran Li Chunchun Wang Kesheng Lin Chengsi Wang Libing Zhu Linyun Han Zhuo Xing * Ying Yu * Institute of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, College of Physical Science and Technology, Central China Normal University, Wuhan 430079, Hubei, China Institute of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology College of Physical Science and Technology Central China Normal University Wuhan Hubei 430079 China Institute of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, College of Physical Science and Technology, Central China Normal University, Wuhan 430079, Hubei, China * Corresponding author. Neutral oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a crucial half-reaction for electrocatalytic chemical production under mild condition, but with limited development due to low activity and poor stability. Herein, a tungsten-doped cobalt molybdate (WDCMO) catalyst was synthesized for efficient and durable OER under neutral electrolyte. It is demonstrated that catalyst reconstruction is suppressed by W doping, which stabilizes the Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection in CoMoO4 architecture and stimulates to a lower valence state of active sites over the surface phase. Thereby, the surface structure maintains to avoid compound dissolution caused by over-oxidation during OER. Meanwhile, the WDCMO catalyst promotes charge transfer and optimizes *OH intermediate adsorption, which improves reaction kinetics and intrinsic activity. Consequently, the WDCMO electrode exhibits an overpotential of 302 mV at 10 mA cm–2 in neutral electrolyte with an improvement of 182 mV compared with CoMoO4 electrode. Furthermore, W doping significantly improves the electrode stability from 50 h to more than 320 h, with a suppressive potential attenuation from 2.82 to 0.29 mV h–1. This work will shed new light on designing rational electrocatalysts for neutral OER. Graphical Abstract MoO4 tetrahedron in CoMoO4 is fixed by W doping, thus stabilizing the Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection and suppressing the component dissolution and catalyst reconstruction, which exhibits great improvement on the stability and activity for neutral OER. Keywords Neutral oxygen evolution reaction Suppressive catalyst reconstruction Cobalt molybdate Tungsten doping Stability 1 Introduction Green hydrogen generated from electrocatalytic water splitting holds great promise to address energy crisis and environment issues due to its high-energy density and carbon-free production [1–5]. Compared with the half reaction of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) during water splitting, oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is intrinsically sluggish because of the multistep proton-electron coupled transfer process [6], which significantly hampers the overall efficiency of water electrolysis. Noble-metal-based (e.g., Ir and Ru) materials are currently the benchmarks of OER catalysts [7], but their rareness prevents the authentic utilization in large-scale application. However, current studies have been mainly focused on the water electrolysis behavior under severe conditions (acidic/alkaline electrolyte) [8–10], and the OER under neutral/mild conditions has not been explored in detail. While the electrochemical water oxidation in neutral electrolytes has the advantage in large-scale application, the mild operating conditions and low environment impacts are beneficial to alleviating equipment corrosion and extending electrolyzer lifespan. Besides, the pH-neutral conditions are needed in electrochemical CO2 reduction and microbial electrolysis cells, since it benefits highest CO2 solubility for efficient CO2 conversion and survivable environment for biological growth, respectively [11]. However, because reactant concentration is several orders of magnitude lower in pH-neutral electrolyte than that in alkaline electrolyte and thus the OER requires additional water adsorption and dissociation processes to provide the adsorbed water molecules (*H2O), the overpotential is generally high (>350 mV at 10 mA cm−2) for neutral OER [12]. Up to now, a fast-growing number of catalysts including Ru-/Ir-based [13,14], Co-based [15,16], Ni-based [17,18], and Mn-based [19] materials, have shown substantial progress in OER performance at pH-neutral. Nonetheless, there has been no virtual breakthrough so far toward practice since these catalysts are not yet up to requirements with sub-350 mV overpotentials at 10 mA cm−2 with prolonged durability of more than 200 h (Table S1). As a promising strategy to improve OER activity, catalyst reconstruction mechanism under neutral media still remains unclear with rare report [20,21]. For instance, when Co-based materials are operated as the anode for alkaline OER, it has been widely demonstrated that the reconstructed CoOOH is the real active phase [22,23]. This mechanism is accessible since the abundant OH- in the alkaline electrolyte can be quickly replenished near the reconstructed metal sites. However, this beneficial strategy of catalyst reconstruction from Co-based materials to CoOOH active phase might become unsound when it comes to a non-alkaline condition. Many previous reports have illustrated that the reconstructed CoOOH is not necessary for non-alkaline OER and the Co-based catalysts directly function as the real active sites [24–28]. The effect of catalyst reconstruction on neutral OER performance deserve being investigated. Cobalt molybdate (CoMoO4, denoted as “CMO”), which consists of CoO6 octahedra and MoO4 tetrahedra linked by Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection, is a typical binary transition metal oxides (TMOs) with much attention for OER [29–31], thus providing a good platform to elucidate the aforementioned problem. Notably, during alkaline OER process, the MoO4 component in binary TMOs is extremely susceptible to leach, which effectively promote the reconstruction of other components to form (oxy)hydroxides in a rich-OH− environment [32,33]. However, in a neutral media, the massive dissolution of MoO4 component in CMO catalyst may result in the destruction of the Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection and thereby poor stability of electrode due to the almost negligible concentration of OH- in the solution. As such, the stability mechanism and improvement strategy of the CoMoO4 catalyst need to be explored to evidence the rational design of durable catalysts for neutral OER. Herein, tungsten doped CoMoO4 was demonstrated to show enhanced stability of CoMoO4 structure for efficient and durable OER at neutral pH. Experiment results as well as theoretical calculations and spectrum characterizations collectively indicated that the introduction of W into CoMoO4 (WDCMO) prevent the surface Co and Mo sites from over-oxidation during OER, thus suppressing the MoO4 compound dissolution and catalyst reconstruction. Moreover, WDCMO demonstrated facilitated charge transfer over the reaction interface and optimized adsorption of reaction intermediates. As a result, under the neutral electrolyte of 1 mol L−1 phosphate buffer solution (PBS, pH = 7.0), the designed WDCMO electrode for OER required the overpotential of only 302 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and can operate stably for more than 320 h, with a significantly slow voltage attenuation compared to the catalysts without W doping. Meanwhile, W doping also improved the HER activity of phosphatized CMO electrode (WDCMP), and the assemble with WDCMO as anode and WDCMP as cathode for overall water splitting exhibited a decent durability for 200 h. This work provides new insight on the catalyst reconstruction mechanism for the development of durable and active TMOs for neutral water oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All raw chemicals were used directly without further purification. Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), sodium tungstate (Na2WO4), sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4), ammonium fluoride (NH4F), urea ((NH2)2CO), chlorine hydride (HCl), and ethanol (C2H5OH) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Nafion (117 solution, 5 wt%) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Nickel foam (99.99%, thickness: 1.5 mm) was purchased from Changde Liyuan New Materials Co., Ltd. Deionized water (DIW, > 18 MΩ cm−2) was used for the material synthesis and electrolyte preparation. Tetramethylammonium sulfate was purchased from Aladdin. 2.2 Electrode preparation In a typical synthesis of WDCMO electrode, 4 mmol Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 2 mmol Na2MoO4, 4 mmol urea, and 4 mmol NH4F were dissolved into 60 mL DIW thoroughly. After stirring for 0.5 h, 0.2 mmol Na2WO4 was added into the mixed solution. Subsequently, a piece of Ni foam (2 cm × 5 cm) was placed into the solution and the solution was transferred into a 100-mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave to conduct a hydrothermal treatment at 140 °C for 5 h. After cooling to room temperature, the WDCMO electrode was obtained by fully rinsing with ethanol and DIW repeatedly, followed by drying at 60 °C for 10 h under vacuum. In addition, the CMO electrode was prepared by similar synthesis procedures but without adding Na2WO4. And the WDCO electrode was prepared by similar synthesis procedures but without adding Na2MoO4. The WDMO electrode were prepared by similar synthesis procedures but without adding Co(NO3)2·6H2O. The CO electrode was prepared by similar synthesis procedures but without adding Na2WO4 and Na2MoO4. The WDCMP and CMP electrodes were respectively prepared by phosphorization of the WDCMO and CMO samples in a tube furnace under a N2 atmosphere at 350 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1, where 0.5 g NaH2PO2 powders were placed upstream of the tube furnace, and the corresponding samples downstream. The IrO2 electrode was prepared for comparison. Specifically, 40 mg IrO2 and 60 μL Nafion were dispersed in 540 μL ethanol and 400 μL DIW in a small sealed tube for the formation of ink. The mixture ink was ultrasonicated for 30 min, and the dispersion was then coated onto a Ni foam substrate with the loading mass of 5 mg cm−2, followed by dried in air overnight. 2.3 Material characterizations The surface morphology and nanostructure of as-prepared electrodes were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL JSM7900F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL 2100F) equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) (SEM, Oxford Ultim Max 65; TEM, QUANTAX 200-TEM). The chemical structure of electrodes was studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on an X’Pert PRO diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation and Raman spectra on a HORIBA LabRAM Spectrometer with a laser of 532 nm. The chemical composition state was tested by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a ThermoFischer system (ESCALAB Xi+). In the chamber where XPS is measured under a high vacuum environment, the surface etching of the sample was conducted using an argon ion gun with the size of etching spot of 1.5 mm and etching voltage of 3000 eV. The element ratio of electrodes was measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) with an Agilent ICP-OES 5110. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and X-ray emission spectrometry (XES) were collected on RapidXAFS (Anhui Absorption Spectroscopy Analysis Instrument Co., Ltd.), and Si (533) spherically bent crystal analyzer was used for Co element. The obtained XAFS results were processed in Athena software [34]. Hama Fortran code was used for the wavelet transform (WT) analysis [35]. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum was conducted at room temperature on EMXmicro-6/1EMXmicro-6/1 (Bruke, Germany). 2.4 Electrochemical measurements All electrochemical tests were performed at room temperature on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation. The as-prepared electrode was used as the working electrode, while graphite carbon rod electrode and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) were applied as the counter and reference electrode, respectively. The potentials were transformed to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) through the Nernst equation (E RHE = E SCE + 0.059 × pH + 0.241). The electrolyte is 1 mol L−1 PBS, whose pH was modulated to be 7. The catalytic activity was performed by backward linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) from positive to negative direction at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 with 90% IR-compensation. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves with different scan rates were recorded during the non-Faradaic region to determine electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl), which was calculated by plotting the Δj (Δj = j a ‒ j c, where j a is the anodic current and j c is the cathodic current at the middle voltage) against the scan rate, and the slope value of the curve is estimated to be C dl. The specific capacitance was found to be 35 μF cm−2 [11]. The electrochemical active surface areas (ECSA) of the electrode were evaluated from the following g equation: ECSA = C dl/35 cmECSA 2. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was measured with the AC impedance from 105 to 10−1 Hz and an amplitude of 5 mV at a potential of 1.5 V (vs. RHE). Chronopotentiometry curve at a constant current density was performed to evaluate the stability of electrode. The CO stripping measurements were carried out to compare the adsorption of as-prepared electrode towards *OH in 1 mol L−1 KOH solution using a H-type electrolytic cell [36]. An AEM electrolyzer single cell (Dioxide Materials, America) was assembled by using the WDCMO and WDCMP as the anode and cathode (1 cm × 1 cm), respectively, and anion exchange membrane (Fumasep® FAA-3-PK-130, Germany) was utilized to separate the anode and cathode. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) calculation methods All of the calculations were performed by using Vienna ab initio program package (VASP) [37]. The exchange and correlation effects of the electrons were described by using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [38] functional of a generalized gradient approximation (GGA) method [39]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe the electron-ion interaction. Spin polarization was considered. The cutoff energy of the plane-wave was set as 500 eV. Conjugate-gradient algorithm was employed to relax the ions into their instantaneous ground state. The structure involved were fully relaxed with the energy and force convergences less than 1 × 10−6 eV and 0.03 eV Å−1, respectively. The (5×3×4) k-point mesh was used for k-space integration in CoMoO4 structure relaxations. When investigating the doping of W into CoMoO4, it is considered that there are two types of MoO4 tetrahedra in the CoMoO4 lattice: MoO4 tetrahedra connected to only one CoO6 octahedron, and MoO4 tetrahedra connected to two CoO6 octahedra. W atoms were used to replace these two types of MoO4 tetrahedra to obtain two new structures, and the formation energies of these two new structures were calculated using the following formula: E f = E Doped – E Undoped - 2μ W + 2μ Mo, in which E Doped and E Undoped is the energy of the doped and undoped structure, μ w and μ Mo is the chemical potential of the W and Mo atom, obtained by calculating their corresponding stable metal structure (both W and Mo are body-centered cubic structure). Based on the information obtained from TEM, the (400) facet of CoMoO4 as the main surface was selected for simulating the OER reaction. The (2×3×1) k-point mesh was used for structure relaxation of the surface. For the calculation of OER free energy change, a vacuum layer of 20 Å was set to avoid error caused by crystal periodicity. The widely accepted method to model the OER process is a four-electron reaction pathway: (1) H2O + * → OH* + H+ + e− (2) OH* → O* + H+ + e− (3) H2O + O* → OOH* + H+ + e− (4) OOH* → * + O2 + H+ + e− where * represents an active site on the bare catalyst surface and OH*, O*, and OOH* denote different adsorbed intermediates. For each individual step, the Gibbs free energy ΔGi (i = 1, 2, 3, 4) can be calculated using the expression: (5) ΔGi = ΔE + ΔZPE – TΔS where ΔE is the total energy difference between the reactant and product molecules in the reactions, ΔZPE and TΔS are the changes in the zero-point energy and the entropic contribution, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure characterizations W element was introduced into CoMoO4 by a facile hydrothermal method as shown in Fig. 1(a) . And the amount of each element was determined by ICP-OES (Table S2). SEM images show that the introduction of W does not affect the pristine morphology of either mono- or binary TMOs (Figs. 1(b) and S1−S5). Among them, the WDCMO sample exhibits an interlaced nanosheet structure, which provides the prepared self-supported electrode with a large specific surface area to expose numerous active sites. Typically, a similar morphology is observed for the WDCMO and CMO samples, eliminating the performance difference caused by the morphology. Further, the intensity distribution image of transmission electron microscopy displays the abundant grain boundary and dispersed regions with the lattice defects marked by blue circles (Figs. 1(c), 1(d), and S6). It has been reported that the abundant grain boundary and oxygen vacancy are favorable for the redox reactions with active electronic structures [40]. However, if the defect concentration is too high, the catalyst structure will be easily damaged. The result of EPR spectrum shows that the incorporation of W decreases the oxygen vacancy (Ov) concentration compared to CoMoO4 (Fig. S7), which can be help for the structural stability. In addition, the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern shown in the inset of Fig. 1(c) displays well-resolved diffraction rings belonging to the (400) and (024) planes of CoMoO4 referred to Powder Diffraction File (JCPDS #21-0868). And the enlarged TEM images demonstrate the interplanar crystal spacing of about 0.24 nm (Fig. 1(e)), indexing to the (400) facet of cobalt molybdate [41]. Accordingly, the (004) facet was subsequently chosen the surface of model for theoretical computation. Furthermore, the EDS elemental mapping distribution map suggests the uniform distribution of the individual elements, verifying the homogeneous introduction of W into CoMoO4 (Fig. 1(f)). Meanwhile, although the precursor for material preparation contains Na element, the elemental mapping images exhibit no Na residual after the sample was thoroughly rinsed by water. Therefore, the influence of Na on the electrode performance was excluded in the following discussions. To explore the chemical composition of the material, XRD, Raman spectra, and XPS analyses were conducted. The diffraction peak for CO sample located at 33.4°, 35.2°, and 38.6° are ascribed to the β-Co(OH)2 [42], while only the peaks of Ni foam are shown for the WDCO and WDMO samples (Fig. S8). As shown in Fig. 2(a) , besides the peaks attributed to the Ni foam substrate, the XRD pattern of CMO sample exhibits two sharp peaks at 26.8° and 29.4°, which are indexed to the (002) and (310) planes of CoMoO4, respectively (JCPDS #21-0868). After W doping, no other impurity is detected, while these two peaks obviously shift towards small angle (Fig. 2(b)), suggesting the lattice expansion according to Bragg equation. It is possibly caused by the incorporation of W atoms into the lattice of CoMoO4 owing to the larger atomic radius of W element. In consistent with this phenomenon, the Raman spectra of WDCMO samples exhibit typical peaks at 930 cm−1, which are attributed to CoMoO4 (Figs. 2(c) and S9) [29]. Compared with the 930 cm-1 peak of CMO in the Raman spectrum, the full width at half maxima peak of WDCMO becomes broader by W doping into CoMoO4 (Fig. 2(d)) [43]. These results suggest that W is successfully introduced into the lattice of CMO, which will modulate the electronic structure of CoMoO4. Furthermore, to exclude the element Ni in the catalysts, the WDCMO catalyst powders were extracted by ultrasound process, followed by rinsing thoroughly and centrifugation. The obtained powders were subsequently characterized by XRD and EDS. The XRD pattern only exhibits the peaks ascribed to CoMoO4 (Fig. S10), and no Ni was detected by EDS (Fig. S11). Consequently, the Ni foam substrate, as a porous collector (Fig. S12), functions to provide a large specific surface area for loading WDCMO catalysts, ultimately promoting reaction activity. To validate the changes of electronic structure, XPS was then conducted to reveal the element chemical state (Fig. S13). Referring to the binding energy of peaks in XPS spectra of CMO, the introduction of W into WDCMO slightly shifts the peaks of Co 2p towards higher energy (Fig. 2(e)), as well as the peaks of Mo 3d (Fig. 2(f)). This phenomenon indicates the electron migration from Co and Mo to W over the electrode surface phase, which is likely due to the electronegativity difference between Co/Mo and W. It has been reported that the electron-deficient metal sites are generally favorable for OER, however, if these sites are over oxidized during OER, they are liable to be dissolved into the electrolyte, bringing about a potential venture to electrode stability [44–46]. Especially for the OER under neutral condition, it is crucial to prevent the active sites from over-oxidation over the surface phase. Therefore, the XPS depth analysis profiling by argon ion-beam etching was then conducted to uncover the peak shifts over the bulk phase. It infers that the Co, Mo, and O sites over the surface phase exhibits a lower valence state compared to that over the bulk phase (Figs. 2(e), 2(f), and S14). Correspondingly, the peak of W 4f shifts to the low energy region after surface etching (Fig. 2(g)), which means that more electrons transfer from Co/Mo to W over the bulk phase. This difference in charge distribution between the surface and bulk phase are conductive to keep the Co/Mo active sites from over-oxidation over the surface. And due to the OER process takes place over the surface, the metal active sites at a moderately high valance state possess the reduced risk of the element dissolution caused by the exorbitantly elevated Co/Mo valence state during the OER and then enhances the stability of the CoMoO4 structure. Furthermore, XAS is carried out to disclose the chemical state and local coordination structures of Co element. From the results of X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra for Co K-edge displayed in Fig. 2(h), it is uncovered that the absorption edge shifts toward higher energy for WDCMO compared with CMO sample, while the white line peak of WDCMO exhibits stronger than that of CMO. These point to the higher valance state of Co for WDCMO sample, which is in agreement with the results of XPS. In addition, the Fourier transform (FT) k 3-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra (Fig. 2(i)) for the catalysts show two major peaks at 1.47 and 2.67 Å associated with the Co−O and Co−Co bonds, respectively, which is further evidenced by the WT-EXAFS analysis (Fig. 2(j)). It can be found from the EXAFS fitting results that the WDCMO catalyst exhibits the stretched Co-O distance compared to the CMO catalyst (Fig. S15 and Table S3), indicating the lattice expansion caused by W doping, which is consistent with the results of XRD and Raman spectra. In addition, owing to the reduced oxygen vacancy concentration, the coordination numbers of Co−O and Co−Co bond for WDCMO sample both rise compared to that for CMO sample, which is beneficial to maintain the structural stability. 3.2 Electrochemical OER performance in neutral media The neutral OER performance of the designed electrodes was tested by a typical three-electrode set-up in 1 mol L−1 PBS (pH = 7.0). Firstly, the OER activity was explored by modulating the precursor concentration (Fig. S16). After optimization, the WDCMO electrode shows the lowest overpotential compared to the CMO and other unitary TMO electrodes, as displayed in Fig. 3(a) . The overpotential to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2 requires only 302 mV for WDCMO, which gains an improvement of 182 mV in relative to that for the CMO sample (Fig. 3(b)). Moreover, the WDCMO electrode exhibits the lowest overpotential (449 mV) among all samples at a high current density of 100 mA cm−2, even better than the IrO2 electrode (497 mV). The impact of W doping on reaction kinetics was further evaluated through Tafel slope. As shown in Fig. 3(c), WDCMO shows the lowest Tafel slope value of 94.1 mV dec‒1, in comparison with CMO (101.6 mV dec‒1), WDCO (113.7 mV dec‒1), WDMO (142.8 mV dec‒1), and CO (294.9 mV dec‒1), suggesting the accelerated OER kinetics on W-doped samples. Moreover, the electrochemical active specific surface area (ECSA) of the electrode plays an important role in promoting the reaction activity, which was deduced from the capacitance of electrochemical double layer. It can be found that WDCMO gains the highest capacitance, indicating a largest ECSA on WDCMO for active sites (Figs. S17−S21). To evaluate the intrinsic OER activity, we normalized the current density by corresponding ECSA, and the WDCMO electrode still exhibits the best performance (Fig. 3(d)). Additionally, EIS was employed to measure the impedance during OER, the Nyquist plots of EIS in Fig. 3(e) indicate smaller R s for W-doped samples. Hence, it is proposed that the W doping not only effectively promotes the intrinsic activity of CMO and reaction kinetics, but also facilitate the charge transfer for OER Further, the chronopotentiometry measurement was used to estimate the stability of the electrodes. As shown in Fig. 3(f), W doping significantly improves the stability of the CMO electrode from 50 h with a potential attenuation of 2.82 mV h−1 to be more than 320 h with a suppressive potential attenuation of 0.29 mV h−1. The activity and stability outstrip most previously reported electrocatalysts for neutral OER (Table S1). Meanwhile, the stability of WDCMO at high current density was also performed. Specifically, negligible potential raise was observed during 80 h for WDCMO at a current density of 200 mA cm−2 (Fig. S22). Thus, the stability of CMO is significantly improved by W doping, which will be investigated in detail below. 3.3 Investigation of catalyst stability and reaction kinetics To gain the insight into the origin for the strengthened stability of the WDCMO electrode, XPS analysis of the electrode after OER (denoted as “WDCMO-OER” and “CMO-OER”) was performed (Fig. S23). For the surface of the WDCMO-OER electrode, no distinct changes in the peak position of the Co and Mo elements are observed after OER (Figs. 4(a) and S24), indicating that its chemical structure remains unchanged and Co/Mo site has not been oxidized to a higher valence state during the OER process. In the XPS depth profiling of WDCMO-OER, the raised valence states of interior Co and Mo are found after OER (Figs. 4(b) and S25), which is probably caused by the continuous positive bias for the electrode. However, as the reaction occurs over the surface, the elevated valence of the internal metal elements does not lead to component dissolution. Interestingly, a new peak attributed to the low-valance W component emerges for both internal and external XPS signal of W 4f (Figs. 4(c) and 4(d)), primary resulting from the variable valence state of W species due to that extremely high electronegativity of W. It should be noted that although the W site attracts electrons over the surface, the valence state of Co and Mo sites keep unchanged during OER. Considering these results, it comes to a reasonable inference that the doped W stabilizes the Co and Mo active sites away from over-oxidation over the surface phase during OER process. It thus suppresses the element dissolution, especially for MoO4 component, which is likely the reason for the enhanced stability by W doping. Moreover, SEM and XRD analysis were conducted to demonstrate the structure of WDCMO-OER and CMO-OER. The WDCMO electrode maintained the initial nanosheet structure after OER (Fig. S26). However, the nanosheets of CMO-OER electrode became smaller, which may be due to the dissolution of the catalyst (Fig. S27). It was further confirmed by the XRD, where the signal of CoMoO4 for the CMO-OER electrode declined and that ascribed to Co(OH)2 species appeared (Fig. 4(e)). These results verify the afore mentions that the dissolution of the MoO4 tetrahedron in CoMoO4 structure leads to the conversion of CoO6 octahedron to Co(OH)2, but this phenomenon is unfavorable for the stability of CMO electrode during neutral OER process as shown in Fig. 3(f). Nevertheless, these hydroxide species are not detected for WDCMO-OER electrode with the pristine CoMoO4 structure (Fig. 4(e)), indicating that the introduction of W can stabilize the Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection, thereby inhibiting the dissolution of MoO4 and improving the stability. The fewer Mo dissolution was subsequently validated by ICP-OES for the WDCMO-OER electrode compared to the CMO-OER electrode (Fig. 4(f)). Furthermore, the influence of W doping on the CoMoO4 structure was investigated by analyzing the phase transition of WDCMO and CMO directly immersed in 1 mol L−1 KOH at different times (denoted as “WDCMO-KOH” and “CMO-KOH”, respectively). As shown in Fig. 4(g), all the Raman peaks assigned to the CoMoO4 almost disappeared after immersion of 60 min on the CMO-KOH, but lasted longer on WDCMO-KOH. Meanwhile, the new Raman peak at about 525 cm−1 appeared after 300 min, which is ascribed to the emerged Co(OH)2 [47]. This is further supported by the XRD patterns. The XRD peak related to Co(OH)2 appears even at 10 mins, and then continues to intensify (Fig. S28). These results suggest that the MoO4 tetrahedron in CoMoO4 structure becomes unassociated with the CoO6 octahedron for the undoped CMO-KOH during the immersion. The disruption of the Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection results in the dissolution of MoO4 compound, following by the timely surface reconstruction of the catalyst to generate the Co(OH)2 phase in an OH−-rich environment. In sharp contrast, for WDCMO-KOH sample dipped in the same solution, the initial signals of Raman spectrum belonging to the CoMoO4 structure are still observed at 300 min, although the occurrence of Co(OH)2 phase at the end of measurement (Fig. 4(h)). And the peak assigned to Co(OH)2 on WDCMO-KOH appears much later than that on CMO (Fig. S29). The generation of Co(OH)2 species are further proved by XES (Fig. 4(i)). The Co Kβ main peak is ascribed to the electron transition from 3p to 1s, subsequently emitting X-ray. After immersed in KOH for 300 minutes, the signal of Co Kβ for WDCMO-KOH electrode exhibits a fewer redshift compared to that for CMO-KOH electrode. This redshift towards low energy reveals the generation of Co(OH)2 species, which is caused by the weaker coordination between Co and OH compared to the coordination between Co and O [48,49]. Notably, as mentioned in the introduction, the reconstruction from CoO6 octahedron to Co(OH)2 phase caused by the leaching of MoO4 tetrahedron in the CoMoO4 structure does occur under an alkaline environment, but not a neutral condition due to the almost negligible OH-. This point is evidenced by the XRD results, which demonstrate the remained peaks ascribed to CoMoO4 structure without any Co(OH)2 phase for both the CMO and WDCMO electrodes when immersed in 1 mol L−1 PBS after 300 min (Figs. S30 and S31). It is therefore proposed that the matter to hold the stable CoMoO4 structure is the key to enhance the durability of the electrode under neutral electrolyte. Consequently, W doping restrains the MoO4 dissolution and provokes the steady CoMoO4 structure, resulting in the durable WDCMO electrode for neutral OER. Subsequently, operando EIS and in-situ Raman spectrum were performed to investigate the electrocatalytic reaction kinetics. As shown in Figs. 5(a) and 5(b) , the operando Bode phase plots demonstrate the variation of phase angle with frequency at different voltages. The peaks at high and low frequency are derived from the electron conduction within the inner layer of the electrode and the charge transfer over the interface between the electrolyte and the electrode, respectively. Typically, the high phase angle at low frequency and low phase angle at high frequency express that the whole electron transfer impedance primarily arises from the electrolyte-catalyst interface rather than the catalyst interior [50]. This is mainly originated from the extremely low concentration of reactants in the neutral medium. At the high frequency, the phase angle of WDCMO is almost constant and lower than that of CMO as increasing voltage (Fig. 5(c)), denoting the smaller electron conduction impedance of WDCMO electrode. At the low frequency, the phase angle of WDCMO and CMO shows comparability at voltages below 1.3 V in the non-OER region (Fig. 5(d)). Notably, the dropped magnitude of phase angle from 1.4 to 1.45 V for WDCMO is greater than that for CMO, implying earlier onset of OER and improved reaction activity after W doping [51]. As a result, taking both interfacial charge transfer and internal electron conductivity into account, the WDCMO electrode exhibits a lower charge transfer impedance than that of CMO, suggesting its faster kinetics of adsorbed oxygen-containing reactive species during the neutral OER process. Furthermore, CV measurements of WDCMO electrode show almost identical curves during consecutive scans (Fig. S32), indicative of the nearly no catalyst reconstruction. In addition, in-situ Raman spectra were used to reveal the evolution of oxygen-containing reactive species on the surface of the WDCMO electrode during the OER process, which was collected from the open circuit potential (OCP) to 1.55 V (vs. RHE). As shown in Fig. 5(e), the Raman peaks assigned to CoMoO4 remain essentially unchanged throughout the OER, evidencing its stable structure. Meanwhile, at 1.4 V, the Raman peaks located at 986 cm−1 and 1075 cm−1 can be observed, which are referred to the adsorption of reaction intermediate OOH* and OO*, respectively [52]. Tetramethylammonium cation (TMA+) is often used to detect the lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) through precisely binding to oxygen-containing negative ions such as O2− and O2 − and ultimately lowering LOM activity [53]. In this regard, the OER activity of the WDCMO electrode was collected in 1 mol L−1 Na2SO4 and (TMA)2SO4, which exhibited that there was little difference in the activity tested in these two electrolytes (Fig. S33). These results certify that the OER mechanism of WDCMO follows the adsorption evolution mechanism (AEM) pathway, which provides guidance for DFT calculations. 3.4 Theoretical analysis DFT calculations were used to explore the mechanism of the enhanced electrochemical activity and stability by W doping (Figs. S34 and S35). Due to the similar structure of MoO4 2− and WO4 2− as well as the lower formation energy of W replacing the Mo site than the Co site (Fig. 6(a) ), the theoretical models were constructed by substituting Mo site in MoO4 tetrahedra with W element. There are two types of MoO4 tetrahedra in the CoMoO4 lattice, MoO4 tetrahedra connected with one or two CoO6 octahedron, the formation energy of W doping (W1 and W2) however exhibits negligible difference between these two new structures (Fig. S36), inspiring that both two Mo sites were replaced by W in the following DFT models (denoted as “WDCMO”). Subsequently, the Bader charge distribution of the outer (W1) and inner (W2) elements in the WDCMO structure was evaluated, and these results point out the electron flows from Co to W (Figs. 6(b) and S37). Notably, the W doping results in low valence state over the surface Co sites compared to that over inner Co sites, which is consistent with the XPS results. This phenomenon ensures that the active sites on surface be protected from dissolution owing to over-oxidation during OER. Furthermore, electron localization function diagram displayed the lower value over the doped W site compared to Mo site as shown in Figs. 6(c) and S38, in indicative of the electron dislocation by W doping and the promoted electron transfer. The orbital compositions of the O p bands were then considered to reveal the improved stability of WDCMO through the projected density of states (PDOS) as shown in Fig. 6(d). The PDOS analysis demonstrates a notable upward shift in the p-band center of O for WDCMO (−3.21 eV) in comparison to CMO (−3.94 eV), suggesting the increased covalency of metal-O bonds through W doping [54]. These results point to the stabilized Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection and thus lead to the durable electrode. Meanwhile, the calculated d-band centers of Co and Mo for WDCMO were both near towards the Fermi level compared with CMO, disclosing the superior electron conductivity and strengthened adsorption to *OOH species during OER over WDCMO, thereby increasing the possibility of AEM pathway [54–56]. This result is in line with the aforementioned result of in-situ Raman spectra, determining the AEM pathway for subsequently calculating the energy profiles for OER. In addition, the more favorable OH− adsorption over WDCMO electrode is further proved by the CO stripping experiments compared with that over CMO electrode (Fig. 6(e)), manifesting the beneficial initial reactant conversion [36]. The energy profiles for OER path upon the surface sites of WDCMO and CMO were analyzed, which demonstrated that W doping modulates the adsorption/desorption of the reaction intermediates (Figs. 6(f), and S39−S43). The potential-determining step (PDS) over Co/Mo sites for WDCMO and CMO samples was collected. Among the adsorbed sites, PDS over Mo sites for WDCMO showed the lowest energy barrier compared with that over Co sites, indicating that the reaction mainly occurs over the Mo sites (Table S4). Moreover, combined with the free energy for key intermediates over the doped/undoped electrocatalysts, it can be found that the PDS associated with the highest energy of WDCMO and CMO is the conversion from O* to OOH*, in consistency with the previous reports [52]. PDS for WDCMO exhibits the OER energy barrier of 1.533 eV, which is much lower than that for undoped CMO (2.359 eV). In this way, W doping modulates the electronic structure of CMO and facilitates the adsorption of intermediates for OER, resulting in WDCMO catalysts exhibiting advantageous OER thermodynamics. Accordingly, W doping not only accelerates the reaction kinetics, but also stabilizes the Co-O-Mo point-to-point connections in the CoMoO4 structure, which in turn restrains the fracture of MoO4 tetrahedron and CoO6 octahedron and contributes to a stable CoMoO4 structure (Fig. 6(g)). 3.5 Overall water splitting at neutral The aforementioned discussions have established that W doping boosts the neutral OER activity and stability of CoMoO4. Based on this point, the overall water splitting coupling WDCMO with WDCMP (phosphatized WDCMO) and CMO with CMP (phosphatized CMO) as anode and cathode were set up, respectively. The phosphatized samples demonstrate the uniform distribution of each element with the similar nanosheet morphology compared with the pristine samples (Figs. S44−S47). Meanwhile, the XRD results of the phosphatized samples show that the peaks attributed to CoMoO4 structure disappear, while some new peaks ascribed to CoMoP (JCPDS #32-0300) and Co2P (JCPDS #32-0306) species besides the signal of Ni foam substrate can be seen for both WDCMP and CMP samples (Fig. S48), in indicative of the phosphate electrode synthesis. Regarding as HER performance, it is found that both the phosphorylation process and W doping improve the HER activity of CMO, as shown in Fig. 7(a) . At a current density of −10 mA cm−2, the WDCMP electrode requires overpotential of 83 mV, which is significantly lower than that of CMP electrode (140 mV), WDCMO electrode (173 mV), and CMO electrode (243 mV) (Fig. 7(b)). Additionally, the current density at a potential of −0.2 V (vs. RHE) achieved by WDCMP is more than twice as that by CMP. And the WDCMP electrode exhibits a smaller Tafel slope compared to CMP, suggesting faster HER kinetics (Fig. 7(c)). Furthermore, the reaction activity of overall water splitting in the two-electrode test system at neutral pH is significantly improved by W doping for WDCMP||WDCMO comparing to CMP||CMO (Fig. 7(d)). The assembled system operates stably for 200 h with a negligible voltage attenuation, superior to the operation of 90 h for CMO||CMP (Fig. 7(e)). This further verifies that the doping of W functions with a significant enhancement on the performance and stability of CoMoO4. Furthermore, an AEM water electrolysis device was assembled using 1 mol L−1 PBS as the electrolyte and WDCMO and WDCMP as the anode and cathode, respectively. It sustains the operation for 100 h under the large current density of 300 mA cm−2 (Fig. S49), indicating its practical application potential. 4 Conclusions In summary, a facile strategy with tungsten doping was developed to modulate CoMoO4 for OER under neutral condition. The introduction of W into CoMoO4 not only promotes the neutral OER kinetics through facilitating charge transfer and optimizing the adsorption of intermediates, but also improve the stability of electrode through keeping Co and Mo sites over the surface phase with low valance and stabilizing the Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection in CoMoO4 structure for preventing the component from dissolution with the suppressive catalyst reconstruction. In addition, DFT calculations demonstrate that the modulation on reaction intermediates caused by W doping greatly contributes to the reduced energy barrier of the potential-determining step, thus facilitating the OER process. Accordingly, the doped sample demonstrates significantly improvement on OER activity and stability under neutral condition. A low overpotential of 302 mV at 10 mA cm−2 with a durable operation for over 320 h were achieved on WDCMO electrode, which is 182 mV lower than that on CMO electrode with a sub-50 h stability. And the overall water electrolysis based on the WDCMO electrode for OER and WDCMP electrode for HER achieves lower energy consumption and prolonged stability with decreased potential attenuation. Given further perception in the effect of catalyst reconstruction on neutral OER stability, we expect that this design concept holds great promise for developing ideal materials for neutral water electrolysis. coredata.dc:description: Neutral oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a crucial half-reaction for electrocatalytic chemical production under mild condition, but with limited development due to low activity and poor stability. Herein, a tungsten-doped cobalt molybdate (WDCMO) catalyst was synthesized for efficient and durable OER under neutral electrolyte. It is demonstrated that catalyst reconstruction is suppressed by W doping, which stabilizes the Co-O-Mo point-to-point connection in CoMoO4 architecture and stimulates to a lower valence state of active sites over the surface phase. Thereby, the surface structure maintains to avoid compound dissolution caused by over-oxidation during OER. Meanwhile, the WDCMO catalyst promotes charge transfer and optimizes *OH intermediate adsorption, which improves reaction kinetics and intrinsic activity. Consequently, the WDCMO electrode exhibits an overpotential of 302 mV at 10 mA cm–2 in neutral electrolyte with an improvement of 182 mV compared with CoMoO4 electrode. Furthermore, W doping significantly improves the electrode stability from 50 h to more than 320 h, with a suppressive potential attenuation from 2.82 to 0.29 mV h–1. This work will shed new light on designing rational electrocatalysts for neutral OER.
